title: Make session hooks fast and lean

brief.why: Session startup takes ~400ms, mostly Python interpreter startup for 3 arc CLI reads. arc-tactical fires on every prompt at ~30ms. The guard pattern exists because hooks are expensive enough that accidental firing matters. Strip cruft (health checks, permission scan, config sync), replace Python reads with jq (~3ms), and the guard becomes unnecessary.
brief.what: 1. Strip sync-config pull, quick_health_check, sync-skill-permissions from session-start.sh 2. Replace 3 arc CLI reads in open-context.sh with jq on items.jsonl 3. Replace arc CLI read in arc-tactical.sh with jq on items.jsonl 4. Register all hook events in install.sh (SessionEnd, UserPromptSubmit, PostToolUse) 5. Remove subagent guards from all hooks 6. Test: session start timing, arc-tactical timing, subagent invocation
brief.done: Session start under 100ms. arc-tactical under 10ms. No subagent guards needed because hooks are cheap enough that accidental firing is harmless. install.sh registers all hook events.

title: Find proper home for arc-tactical.sh

brief.why: arc-tactical.sh lives as a standalone file in ~/.claude/hooks/ — not in claude-suite, not in the arc repo. It enforces arc's draw-down pattern but isn't managed by any install process. If arc evolves its tactical format, this hook needs manual updating.
brief.what: 1. Decide: does it belong in arc repo (it's arc-specific) or claude-suite (it's session infrastructure)? 2. Move it to the chosen repo 3. Update install.sh to symlink/register it 4. Remove standalone copy from claude-config
brief.done: arc-tactical.sh has a source repo and is installed via a managed process. No orphaned standalone files.

title: Create shared guard.sh library

brief.why: The identical 15-line subagent guard is copy-pasted across four scripts (session-start.sh, session-end.sh, arc-tactical.sh, sync-config.sh). If the detection logic needs to change (e.g. aboyeur workers use a new flag), four files need updating independently. Fork bomb incident (bd19f03) showed guards matter.
brief.what: 1. Create shared guard.sh with guard_interactive function 2. Each hook sources it: source guard.sh && guard_interactive || exit 0 3. Update all four scripts to use shared guard 4. Test: subagent sessions still suppressed, interactive sessions still work
brief.done: Guard logic lives in one file. Hooks source it. Changing detection logic is a single-file edit.

brief.done: A new contributor can read the README and understand: what claude-suite is, what the protocol guarantees, and where skills live.

title: Harden handoff section parsing in open-context.sh

brief.why: The sed extraction of ## Done, ## Next, ## Gotchas from handoffs is brittle. Slightly different headings (## What we did, ## Gotcha) or markdown formatting (bold, nested lists) produce blank output. The briefing silently degrades.
brief.what: 1. Test current parsing against all existing handoffs in ~/.claude/handoffs/ 2. Identify format variations that break extraction 3. Make parsing more tolerant (fuzzy heading match, handle nested markdown) 4. Add fallback: if sections can't be extracted, show first 5 lines of handoff
brief.done: Parsing works against all existing handoffs. Format variations produce degraded but non-empty output.

title: Handle no-zoom case when arc show --current is empty

brief.why: The 'Last worked on' zoom depends on arc show --current returning an active tactical step. At session start (common case), no tactical steps are active — the zoom silently disappears. User sees outcomes but no action-level detail until they pick one.
brief.what: 1. Decide fallback: most recently completed action's outcome? Handoff-inferred outcome? Just skip? 2. Implement chosen fallback in open-context.sh 3. Test: fresh session with no active tactical, session mid-work, session after arc done
brief.done: Briefing shows meaningful zoom section even when no tactical steps are active.

title: File arc-read.sh field report to arc repo

brief.why: arc-read.sh reads items.jsonl directly with jq, bypassing the Python CLI. The arc repo should know about this consumer — if the JSONL schema evolves, arc-read.sh queries could silently diverge. The jq-for-reads pattern (Python for writes, jq for reads) is a reusable architectural decision worth documenting.
brief.what: 1. Write field report in arc repo documenting arc-read.sh as a JSONL consumer 2. Document which fields are read (.tactical, .status, .parent, .order, .title, .id, .type, .waiting_for) 3. Propose schema stability guarantee or versioning
brief.done: Arc repo has a field report acknowledging jq consumers of items.jsonl.

title: Document ready vs list numbering divergence

brief.why: arc-read.sh ready renumbers actions sequentially (1,2,3) while list uses the item's .order field. Tests document this but nothing explains *why* or whether consumers can rely on stable numbering.
brief.what: 1. Add comment in arc-read.sh explaining the numbering difference 2. Note in HOOKS_AND_SCRIPTS.md that ready output uses sequential numbering
brief.done: A developer reading arc-read.sh or its docs understands that ready renumbers and list preserves .order
